summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case (20-CR-330). The order addresses redaction disputes regarding the government's omnibus memorandum and exhibits, ruling that certain proposed redactions are unnecessary as the information is already public record. The government is ordered to file the documents with limited redactions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the court order (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, ruling on redaction disputes in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: The court issued an order regarding redactions in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, referenced as the basis for the current ruling.

events.title: Prior Court Order
events.description: An earlier court order, also referenced as a basis for the current ruling on redactions.

events.title: Parties' Joint Letter
events.description: The parties submitted a joint letter responding to the court's March 29 order, which is referenced in this ruling.

events.title: Court Issues Redaction Order
events.description: Judge Nathan issues this order, directing the government to file its omnibus memorandum with limited redactions and setting a deadline for redaction proposals on the April 1 joint letter.

keyFacts: The court ruled that redactions proposed by the defendant (Ghislaine Maxwell) for pages 129-134 of a document were unnecessary and overbroad because the information was already part of the public record.
The court approved only limited redactions to 'Exhibit 11' to the Government's brief, except for language already quoted in the public Indictment.
The Government was ordered to publicly file (docket) its omnibus memorandum of law and corresponding exhibits by 3:00 p.m. on April 16, 2021, with the court-approved redactions.
The parties were ordered to file their April 1, 2021 joint letter, with a deadline of April 19, 2021, to propose any redactions for that letter.
